bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of MAC FOCK for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
COMES now Mac Fock, of Seattle, King Count, Washington, and respectfully makes this application for a writ of habeas corpus, alleges as follows:

That Mac Fock is imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, at the Port of Seattle, State of Washington, and by the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, or by some agent or representative under and by virtue of either or both of them, under the illegal charge, as your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the fact to be, that he should be deported from the United States of America under and by virtue of the Chinese Exclusion acts.
That said imprisonment and confinement and restraint as aforesaid, is illegal and arises from the following facts:

Your petitioner arrived at port of Seattle on his return from China, on the 21st day of March, A.D. 1913, and ws denied admission by the said Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, at the Port of Seattle, State of Washington.
That thereafter an appeal was taken from the decision

of Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle, to the Secretary of Commerce & Labor (now Secretary of Labor) of the United States, and said excluding decision so made by Ellis De Bruler was affirmed by the Secretary of Labor of the United States, the said officers herein named clearly abusing their discretion and violating the treaty relations between the United States and China, the Chinese Exclusion Acts of the United States, and the Constitution and Amendments thereof of the United States of America, particularly Article 5 of the Amendments of the Constitution of the United States, and Article 14 of such Amendments.

That your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the fact to be, that Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, or the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, or some persons acting by or through or under them, and at their direct command, are about to deport the said Mac Fock, after he has been exercising his rights of citizenship under and by virtue of an order of discharge for a similar and same offence for which they are now seeking to deport hm, for over seventeen (17) years in the United States of America, the sai d order of discharge being in his possession , that is, the possession of said Mac Fock, on the ground that he is a native born Chinese, which said discharge was granted by the United States Commissioner, Filed w. , in the City of St. Albans State of Vermont, on the 12th day of June, A.D. 1896 being, as your petitioner is informed and believes and so states the fact to be, a court of competent jurisdiction both of the person of the petitioner, Mac Fock, and of the subject matter therein set forth, and being duly and regularly authorized and empowered under and by virtue of the laws of the United States of America, to pass upon the matters and things set forth in the
copy of said order of discharge, which is hereto attached and marked Exhibit B., and by reference thereto made a part of this petition, as fully as though set out herein, the same being a true and correct copy of the original order of discharge in the court aforesaid.

That said Mac Fock is one and the same person as was duly and regulary discharged as a native born Chinese, under and by virtue of the order of said Commissioner as aforesaid, and said order of discharge has never been cancelled or set aside by any state or Federal officer of the United States of America, nor by any Federal Court or State Court of the United States of America, nor by any order of any Commissioner of Immigration of the United States of America, from that time until this time, and said petitioner in all the intervening years has exercised all the rights and immunities of a native born citizen under and by virtue of said discharge as aforesaid.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a Writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted, directed to the said Ellis De Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, at the Port of Seattle, State of Washington, and to the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, and to the agent or representative acting by, through or under them, or either of them, commanding him or them to have the body of said Mac Fock before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specificed, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his detention, and said writ, and that he may be restored to liberty according to the habeas corpus act of the United States of America. Dated this 9th day of June, A.D. 1913
